text:
okay i have a thought experiment for you imagine 
you use a notes app in your phone over the next

10 years to record everything you think of 
your thoughts your to-do list your calendar

your contacts will that ruin your memory this is a 
question that i've had for a while because it was

actually the topic of the first video that i made 
and uploaded to this youtube channel seven years

ago and i've been thinking about how this video 
stacks up to the kinds of things that i make now

so i had it fact checked i haven't watched this in 
seven years because i know the production value is

super dodgy and i'm sure that most of you have 
never seen it so let's dive in okay here we go

i'm a little nervous in 2009 a plane was flying 
from new jersey to buffalo new york as it cruised

on autopilot at 16 000 feet it encountered a 
massive storm front approaching the airport the

plane's controls began to shutter loudly a sign 
the plane was losing lift and might stall the

pilot took action he pulled back on the controls 
lifting the plane's nose this was precisely the

wrong thing to do instead of preventing a stall 
he caused one the plane spun out of control and

plummeted into a house killing all on board both 
the plane and the house kind of look like they

were made by an eight-year-old which is to say 
that if you want to get good at something all you

need to do is to do it for seven years and then 
you'll be able to make really good arts and crafts

it's like the 1000 hour rule all you have to do 
is do this for a thousand hours over the course

of however many years and you'll be great how had 
this pilot forgotten his basic emergency training

is technology ruining our memory so i think 
what we've learned about a lot of aircraft

training over the past few years is that 
maybe the pilot never got their emergency

training in the first place also there's so 
many plane channels now aviation channels

but even like wendover production and 
cgp grey make all of this plain content

was this the first popular plane video we're 
all living in the age of google when we google

one thing in wikipedia another we're not relying 
on our brains but on our fingertips is it making

us dumber the ipad first consider there are two 
types of memory non-declarative memory for skills

emotions and movements like how to ride a bike 
and then there's declarative memory for facts and

information like your phone number or the capital 
of australia is so bad okay my fact checker has

written a note here saying that there's lots of 
other ways we can characterize memory as well

episodic versus semantic retrospective versus 
perspective working memory versus long-term memory

but she didn't write down any other definitions 
of those so if you're interested in further

information on them you'll have to google it so 
when we use technology to look up information

we're extending our declarative memories but is 
that at the expense of what's in our brain okay a

note from my fact checker is that non-declarative 
memory is correct but it's important to note that

non-declarative memories are unconscious so we 
ride a bike we drive maybe subconscious we'd

write a but am i fact checking my fact-checker 
now the hippocampus is a major part of the brain

we use in declarative memory function it gives us 
the ability to retain recall memories about facts

like the largest animal on earth and events 
like your first kiss or the first cd you bought

the formation of new declarative memories relies 
on both the hippocampus and a region around it the

parahippocampal gyrus you know what's interesting 
about the parahippocampal gyrus is that i never

use terms like that anymore because to so many 
people they to most people they mean absolutely

nothing so now i'm more likely to say another area 
of your memory center in your brain or something

like that that is much more vague except it plays 
better into a narrative lessons from vanessa

so what happens when we have information at our 
fingertips and we don't need to remember facts

anymore well the process in our brain of how we 
form retain and recall memories remains the same

what changes is what we choose to form memories 
about okay so on what changes is what we choose to

form memories about i do have a fact-checking note 
that the study is phrased this way but the authors

don't actually show the way that we remember 
things is different from how it was in the past

so maybe it's jumping to conclusions you 
could say instead of remembering more facts

we remember where to find them this is called 
the google effect i think the google effect is

such a cute name still in one study participants 
were told they could later look up the answers

online did not make the effort to remember general 
trivia when asked a question people actually

thought about computers and search engines instead 
of searching their own memories for the answer

the use of external memory systems is 
called transactive memory and is not new

einstein once said i do not carry such information 
in my mind since it is readily available in books

plus we've relied on other people to remember 
things for us like a husband or wife now there's

a third wheel in the relationship google i'm 
so embarrassed to laugh at myself and it's

connecting us like never before as for that lump 
of matter inside of our heads that's connected too

for our declarative memory using technology just 
means we're tweaking our memory hard drive so we

remember where the files and folders are where 
we can find information not necessarily the

facts themselves this will probably happen more 
and more as our relationship with devices grows

but it's not necessarily a bad thing fmri scans 
show that for people who are internet savvy

areas of our brains are way more active searching 
for information online than when reading a book

in our brains the hippocampus is still working 
the same way we're just choosing to retain the

most efficient way to find information and 
that's usually online we're all sharing the

work of remembering and it makes us collectively 
smarter okay the whole world of fmri studies is

very interesting so this is true but doesn't 
mean that the internet is making us smarter

maybe it's not that prior internet experience is 
causing increased brain activation it could be

that people whose brains are less active 
choose to use the internet less well doesn't

that make us all feel good if we're using the 
internet more and our brains are more active

but this is another interesting 
thing about fmri studies is that

if there is more activity in your brain it means 
there's more blood flow in that area that's how

these scans measure brain activity and what 
does that actually mean it means you're using

more of that area of your brain but does 
that mean that you're smarter in any way

what is smarter how do we measure that this is 
where fact checking just becomes a whole debate

it's actually pretty adaptive the only 
disadvantage is when you need knowledge

on the fly for split second decisions all you can 
search is that lump of matter inside your head

if you have a burning psychology

and subscribe to braincraft for a new

but i don't know if i'll be able to answer all

okay this is my last fact-checking comment overall 
the way the internet is changing the way we learn

think and remember is probably pretty complicated 
and not fully understood welcome to social science

research i actually asked my fact checker to 
give this video a mark like it was a university

assignment and she has given it a B grade but she 
has written that most people and the scientists

who wrote the first study generally want to make a 
cohesive straightforward story but memory is super

complicated and there will always be nuance and 
contradictory findings but overall i'm actually

pleasantly surprised by the video i thought it was 
going to be terrible and it had a nice story there

was some cute bits of animation even if they were 
kind of dodgy and some jokes maybe i don't make

enough effort to make jokes anymore and i think 
i had such a low expectation of this going in

that i'm very pleased and surprised which is why 
we all need to realign our expectations of life

on a more serious note when i started doing 
this seven years ago i was using an old camera

and whatever light was coming through my window 
and now i have a whole community i have lots of

documentaries on my channel i have a youtube 
original look how far we've come i'm feeling

very grateful to have had a lot of opportunities 
that youtube has brought so thank you for watching

thank you for subscribing and my biggest thanks

if you have the means and you would like to join
